20110118180026.000|20110118180029.000|TR0|information you had out there for the 
20110118180029.000|20110118180031.000|TR0|public to see.
20110118180031.000|20110118180033.000|TR0|

20110118180036.000|20110118180038.000|TR0|this little program you might know as 
20110118180038.000|20110118180041.000|TR0|Facebook.  Now, the news is littered, 
20110118180041.000|20110118180043.000|TR0|these days, with privacy concerns over the 
20110118180043.000|20110118180046.000|TR0|social media giant.  It's been one issue 
20110118180046.000|20110118180048.000|TR0|after another with those guys, over the 
20110118180048.000|20110118180051.000|TR0|years, to do with privacy. The most recent 
20110118180051.000|20110118180053.000|TR0|involves your telephone number being 
20110118180053.000|20110118180056.000|TR0|handed over to developers of third-party 
20110118180056.000|20110118180058.000|TR0|applications you may choose to use on 
20110118180058.000|20110118180100.000|TR0|Facebook.
20110118180100.000|20110118180103.000|TR0|
20110118180103.000|20110118180105.000|TR0|So, last Friday -- last Friday evening I 
20110118180105.000|20110118180108.000|TR0|should say, Facebook gave app developers 
20110118180108.000|20110118180110.000|TR0|access to your phone number and address if 
20110118180110.000|20110118180113.000|TR0|you decided to use an app on Facebook.  
20110118180113.000|20110118180115.000|TR0|Well, late yesterday, they said they were 
20110118180115.000|20110118180118.000|TR0|suspending the feature and updating it, 
20110118180118.000|20110118180120.000|TR0|based on feedback they had received, to 
20110118180120.000|20110118180122.000|TR0|make people more aware of when they were 
20110118180122.000|20110118180125.000|TR0|granting access to personal data.
20110118180125.000|20110118180127.000|TR0|

20110118180130.000|20110118180132.000|TR0|networking sites, you have much more of 
20110118180132.000|20110118180135.000|TR0|your personal information out there for 
20110118180135.000|20110118180137.000|TR0|the world to see. Not just your address

20110118181032.000|20110118181034.000|TR0|true.  We should all be responsible for

20110118181036.000|20110118181039.000|TR0|But let's flip it here, you know, Facebook 
20110118181039.000|20110118181041.000|TR0|has presented itself as a trusted place to 
20110118181041.000|20110118181044.000|TR0|hold your information that, you know, you 
20110118181044.000|20110118181046.000|TR0|share with people you want, you can -- you 
20110118181046.000|20110118181049.000|TR0|know, there's a privacy policy page that 
20110118181049.000|20110118181051.000|TR0|-- you know, that says beware, you know, 
20110118181051.000|20110118181054.000|TR0|of third parties and check out third 
20110118181054.000|20110118181056.000|TR0|parties.
20110118181056.000|20110118181058.000|TR0|

20110118181106.000|20110118181108.000|TR0|you've seen is the Facebook philosophy is

20110118183208.000|20110118183211.000|TR0|
20110118183211.000|20110118183213.000|TR0|We see this all the time, where they say 
20110118183213.000|20110118183215.000|TR0|in private "oh, we're really tough, we're 
20110118183215.000|20110118183218.000|TR0|really tough", but in public they're going 
20110118183218.000|20110118183220.000|TR0|to be a lot more diplomatic because, you 
20110118183220.000|20110118183223.000|TR0|know, that's kind of where they need to be 
20110118183223.000|20110118183225.000|TR0|in order to try to keep this relationship 
20110118183225.000|20110118183228.000|TR0|together.  The last thing they want to do 
20110118183228.000|20110118183230.000|TR0|is be too tough and have this whole

20110118183233.000|20110118183235.000|TR0|
